Factor used for splitting double numbers: n = 2^27 + 1 (i.e. {@value}).
Private constructor.

interface.name: Function
interface.javadoc:
Real-valued function that operate on an array or a part of it.
3.1

Operates on an entire array.
array Array to operate on.
the result of the operation.

@param array Array to operate on.
startIndex Index of the first element to take into account.
numElements Number of elements to take into account.
the result of the operation.

class.javadoc:
Create a copy of an array scaled by a value.
arr Array to scale.
val Scalar.
scaled copy of array with each entry multiplied by val.
3.2

Multiply each element of an array by a value.

The array is modified in place (no copy is created).

arr Array to scale val Scalar 3.2

Creates an array whose contents will be the element-by-element addition of the arguments.
a First term of the addition.
b Second term of the addition.
a new array {@code r} where {@code r[i] = a[i] + b[i]}.
DimensionMismatchException if the array lengths differ.
3.1

Creates an array whose contents will be the element-by-element subtraction of the second argument from the first.
a First term.
b Element to be subtracted.
a new array {@code r} where {@code r[i] = a[i] - b[i]}.
DimensionMismatchException if the array lengths differ.
3.1

Creates an array whose contents will be the element-by-element multiplication of the arguments.
a First factor of the multiplication.
b Second factor of the multiplication.
a new array {@code r} where {@code r[i] = a[i] b[i]}.
DimensionMismatchException if the array lengths differ.
3.1

Creates an array whose contents will be the element-by-element division of the first argument by the second.
a Numerator of the division.
b Denominator of the division.
a new array {@code r} where {@code r[i] = a[i] / b[i]}.
DimensionMismatchException if the array lengths differ.

Returns the Cartesian norm (2-norm), handling both overflow and underflow. Translation of the minpack enorm subroutine. The redistribution policy for MINPACK is available here, for convenience, it is reproduced below.

Sort an array in ascending order in place and perform the same reordering of entries on other arrays. For example, if{@code x = [3, 1, 2], y = [1, 2, 3]} and {@code z = [0, 5, 7]}, then{@code sortInPlace(x, y, z)} will update {@code x} to {@code [1, 2, 3]},{@code y} to {@code [2, 3, 1]} and {@code z} to {@code [5, 7, 0]}.
x Array to be sorted and used as a pattern for permutation of the other arrays.
yList Set of arrays whose permutations of entries will follow those performed on {@code x}.
DimensionMismatchException if any {@code y} is not the same size as {@code x}.
NullArgumentException if {@code x} or any {@code y} is null.
3.0

Sort an array in place and perform the same reordering of entries on other arrays. This method works the same as the other{@link #sortInPlace(double[],double[][]) sortInPlace} method, but allows the order of the sort to be provided in the {@code dir}parameter.
x Array to be sorted and used as a pattern for permutation of the other arrays.
dir Order direction.
yList Set of arrays whose permutations of entries will follow those performed on {@code x}.
DimensionMismatchException if any {@code y} is not the same size as {@code x}.
NullArgumentException if {@code x} or any {@code y} is null
3.0

Compute a linear combination accurately. This method computes the sum of the products ai bi to high accuracy. It does so by using specific multiplication and addition algorithms to preserve accuracy and reduce cancellation effects.
It is based on the 2005 paper Accurate Sum and Dot Product by Takeshi Ogita, Siegfried M. Rump, and Shin'ichi Oishi published in SIAM J. Sci. Comput. a Factors. b Factors. Σi ai bi. DimensionMismatchException if arrays dimensions don't match

method.name: linearCombination
method.comment: either we have split infinite numbers or some coefficients were NaNs,
just rely on the naive implementation and let IEEE754 handle this

class.javadoc:
Compute a linear combination accurately.

This method computes a1×b1 + a2×b2 to high accuracy. It does so by using specific multiplication and addition algorithms to preserve accuracy and reduce cancellation effects. It is based on the 2005 paper Accurate Sum and Dot Product by Takeshi Ogita, Siegfried M. Rump, and Shin'ichi Oishi published in SIAM J. Sci. Comput.

a1 first factor of the first term b1 second factor of the first term a2 first factor of the second term b2 second factor of the second term a1×b1 + a2×b2 #linearCombination(double,double,double,double,double,double) #linearCombination(double,double,double,double,double,double,double,double)

method.name: linearCombination
method.comment: the code below is split in many additions/subtractions that may
appear redundant. However, they should NOT be simplified, as they
use IEEE754 floating point arithmetic rounding properties.
as an example, the expression "ca1 - (ca1 - a1)" is NOT the same as "a1"
The variable naming conventions are that xyzHigh contains the most significant
bits of xyz and xyzLow contains its least significant bits. So theoretically
xyz is the sum xyzHigh + xyzLow, but in many cases below, this sum cannot
be represented in only one double precision number so we preserve two numbers
to hold it as long as we can, combining the high and low order bits together
only at the end, after cancellation may have occurred on high order bits
split a1 and b1 as two 26 bits numbers
accurate multiplication a1 * b1
split a2 and b2 as two 26 bits numbers
accurate multiplication a2 * b2
accurate addition a1 * b1 + a2 * b2
final rounding, s12 may have suffered many cancellations, we try
to recover some bits from the extra words we have saved up to now
either we have split infinite numbers or some coefficients were NaNs,
just rely on the naive implementation and let IEEE754 handle this

class.javadoc:
Compute a linear combination accurately.

This method computes a1×b1 + a2×b2 + a3×b3 to high accuracy. It does so by using specific multiplication and addition algorithms to preserve accuracy and reduce cancellation effects. It is based on the 2005 paper Accurate Sum and Dot Product by Takeshi Ogita, Siegfried M. Rump, and Shin'ichi Oishi published in SIAM J. Sci. Comput.

a1 first factor of the first term b1 second factor of the first term a2 first factor of the second term b2 second factor of the second term a3 first factor of the third term b3 second factor of the third term a1×b1 + a2×b2 + a3×b3 #linearCombination(double,double,double,double) #linearCombination(double,double,double,double,double,double,double,double)

method.name: linearCombination
method.comment: the code below is split in many additions/subtractions that may
appear redundant. However, they should NOT be simplified, as they
do use IEEE754 floating point arithmetic rounding properties.
as an example, the expression "ca1 - (ca1 - a1)" is NOT the same as "a1"
The variables naming conventions are that xyzHigh contains the most significant
bits of xyz and xyzLow contains its least significant bits. So theoretically
xyz is the sum xyzHigh + xyzLow, but in many cases below, this sum cannot
be represented in only one double precision number so we preserve two numbers
to hold it as long as we can, combining the high and low order bits together
only at the end, after cancellation may have occurred on high order bits
split a1 and b1 as two 26 bits numbers
accurate multiplication a1 * b1
split a2 and b2 as two 26 bits numbers
accurate multiplication a2 * b2
split a3 and b3 as two 26 bits numbers
accurate multiplication a3 * b3
accurate addition a1 * b1 + a2 * b2
accurate addition a1 * b1 + a2 * b2 + a3 * b3
final rounding, s123 may have suffered many cancellations, we try
to recover some bits from the extra words we have saved up to now
either we have split infinite numbers or some coefficients were NaNs,
just rely on the naive implementation and let IEEE754 handle this

class.javadoc:
Compute a linear combination accurately.

This method computes a1×b1 + a2×b2 + a3×b3 + a4×b4 to high accuracy. It does so by using specific multiplication and addition algorithms to preserve accuracy and reduce cancellation effects. It is based on the 2005 paper Accurate Sum and Dot Product by Takeshi Ogita, Siegfried M. Rump, and Shin'ichi Oishi published in SIAM J. Sci. Comput.

a1 first factor of the first term b1 second factor of the first term a2 first factor of the second term b2 second factor of the second term a3 first factor of the third term b3 second factor of the third term a4 first factor of the third term b4 second factor of the third term a1×b1 + a2×b2 + a3×b3 + a4×b4 #linearCombination(double,double,double,double) #linearCombination(double,double,double,double,double,double)

method.name: linearCombination
method.comment: the code below is split in many additions/subtractions that may
appear redundant. However, they should NOT be simplified, as they
do use IEEE754 floating point arithmetic rounding properties.
as an example, the expression "ca1 - (ca1 - a1)" is NOT the same as "a1"
The variables naming conventions are that xyzHigh contains the most significant
bits of xyz and xyzLow contains its least significant bits. So theoretically
xyz is the sum xyzHigh + xyzLow, but in many cases below, this sum cannot
be represented in only one double precision number so we preserve two numbers
to hold it as long as we can, combining the high and low order bits together
only at the end, after cancellation may have occurred on high order bits
split a1 and b1 as two 26 bits numbers
accurate multiplication a1 * b1
split a2 and b2 as two 26 bits numbers
accurate multiplication a2 * b2
split a3 and b3 as two 26 bits numbers
accurate multiplication a3 * b3
split a4 and b4 as two 26 bits numbers
accurate multiplication a4 * b4
accurate addition a1 * b1 + a2 * b2
accurate addition a1 * b1 + a2 * b2 + a3 * b3
accurate addition a1 * b1 + a2 * b2 + a3 * b3 + a4 * b4
final rounding, s1234 may have suffered many cancellations, we try
to recover some bits from the extra words we have saved up to now
either we have split infinite numbers or some coefficients were NaNs,
just rely on the naive implementation and let IEEE754 handle this

y second array

x first array
y second array

2.2

Returns {@code true} iff both arguments are {@code null} or have same dimensions and all their elements are equal as defined by{@link Precision#equals(double,double)}.
x First array.
y Second array.
{@code true} if the values are both {@code null} or have same dimension and equal elements.

Returns {@code true} iff both arguments are {@code null} or have same dimensions and all their elements are equal as defined by{@link Precision#equalsIncludingNaN(double,double) this method}.
x First array.
y Second array.
{@code true} if the values are both {@code null} or have same dimension and equal elements.
2.2

Normalizes an array to make it sum to a specified value. Returns the result of the transformation 
                  x |-> x  normalizedSum / sum
applied to each non-NaN element x of the input array, where sum is the sum of the non-NaN entries in the input array.

Throws IllegalArgumentException if {@code normalizedSum} is infinite or NaN and ArithmeticException if the input array contains any infinite elements or sums to 0.

Ignores (i.e., copies unchanged to the output array) NaNs in the input array.

values Input array to be normalized normalizedSum Target sum for the normalized array the normalized array. MathArithmeticException if the input array contains infinite elements or sums to zero. MathIllegalArgumentException if the target sum is infinite or {@code NaN}. 2.1
